did.abstract: From 1944 to 1956, the Division of Research in the Natural Sciences was a centralized administrative office that organized and supported research activities of natural science departments and faculty. This collection contains correspondence and reports pertaining to natural science faculty, facilities, and research during the existence of the Division.
did.langmaterial: The material in this collection is in English.

bioghist.head: History
bioghist.p: In 1936, the Buhl Foundation initiated a grant to support natural science research at the University of Pittsburgh. At the onset of World War II, the university also received government contracts in these fields, which necessitated the unified management of grant funds, resources, personnel, and facilities. In 1944, Vice Chancellor Rufus Fitzgerald addressed this need by creating the Division of Research in the Natural Sciences as a centralized administrative office to organize and support research activities in biology, chemistry, physics, geology, psychology, mathematics, astronomy, and related fields. Dr. Herbert E. Longenecker was named the first Dean of the division and he was succeeded by Acting Dean Max A. Lauffer in July 1955. The following year, the undergraduate College was reorganized into three disciplines and this division formed the foundation of the new Division of Natural Sciences with Dr. Lauffer as its Dean.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This collection contains correspondence and reports pertaining to natural science faculty, facilities, and research during the existence of the Division of Research in the Natural Sciences, as well as the years immediately before its creation and after its merger with the Division of Natural Sciences. Also included are departmental meeting minutes, publication lists, and information about the planning and construction of George Hubbard Clapp Hall. In addition, there are several files containing memos and correspondence about other departments and units at the University of Pittsburgh, as well as potential public and private funding sources.
